you may not know that Amazon RDS was started back in 2009 one of the earliest
services in AWS and it was started by some folks who were running the amazon.com database the database that
powers our e-commerce site running one of the world's largest e-commerce databases at the time and they thought
well if we the things that we've learned about running databases is that we can take that and apply it to our customers
databases we can do the same things for our customers in AWS and so they started the core of Amazon RDS started with the
MySQL engine and then over time over the last seven years it's grown we've added
engines we've added features we've added the Amazon Roar engine so and at the time it was sort of a novel
idea why would we have a database service I can just use compute and storage and I can run my own database
but we really wanted to provide a higher level service that took some of the muck
sort of the grunt work out of running your own database it was like provisioning things like patching things
like scaling back up and restore these are things that if you have good DBAs you have good engineers you can build
yourself but they're really not things that necessarily add value for your company and then we provide really these
high availability solutions that I'll talk a lot about leveraging high availability these are things that typically come in commercial databases
at a very expensive price point and we built them right into RDS so from the beginning you can take advantage of
these so why would you use a managed database solution as I mentioned we managed them up we managed to the day to
day grunt work of running a database and that allows you to get more out of your

based engines on over Amazon Aurora stores scales automatically to 64

this allows us to extend the volume very very rapidly so before when you went from say a 2 terabyte volume to a 4
terabyte volume it could take a long time it could take hours now your database was still alive you're still
active you can still use the database but what we were doing is we were copying over all that data to a new set
of volumes and then switching over the instance use that new set of volumes now when we scale we use the elastic volumes
and we simply extend the volume set for Amazon RDS and just a note here Amazon
RDS actually uses multiple volumes behind the scenes multiple EBS volumes we present that to to you as a single
data volume so you don't have to worry about volume geometry or any of this you just sort of say and I want 8 terabytes
so I want 10 terabytes and we'll go provision that for you so there's really no downtime to storage scaling once

first time of scale it will be a little bit slower we have to use the old technique to get it into

basically instantaneous scaling you're also limited in scaling to once every
six hours we do do some optimizations and so we basically keep you from
scaling once every six hours I could change in the future but right now that's the limitation so just be aware when you're scaling to make sure that
you're you've got the size that you want now if you're using provisioned I ops you can change the eye ops value on the

people ask about is how do I manage high availability how do I manage backups how to do all the sort of the day-to-day tasks of running a relational database
so I want to first talk about high availability as I mentioned this is a feature that's typically in the
enterprise version of a lot of our commercial databases and we built it right into Amazon RDS our multi AZ
configuration provides at fault tolerance we have an additional copy of
your database running in a second availability zone as you know most likely an availability zone is a
logically distinct data center in the same region so you get sort of that extra redundancy you get automatic
failover so if we detect anything's going on we can't reach the hosts in the primary if there's a networking problem
there's some sort of infrastructure problem then we will initiate the failover automatically all the data is
synchronously replicated so that you don't have to worry about any data loss during this event and it's super easy to
do you just turn on one button in the console and enable it
so it's not just enough to know that you have a high availability story but what actually happens during a high
availability story you should test this you know so it's great that you've set everything up but do your applications
survive some sort of networking event do they survive when a multi AC failover
happens so this diagram here shows you at a steady state you've got your primary an ec2 host that's the database
server that your database is running on you've got your set EBS volume sets and then you've got a standby in an
additional availability zone number two and they're replicating synchronously now that replication is at the block
level it's not a logical replication it's actually physically replicating the the storage blocks and there's a third
party here that's monitoring these two and making sure that it can see both of them and maintaining the quorum so that
they make sure that there's only one that thinks it's the primary and the only one that thinks it's the secondary so that they don't get effectively a
split brain syndrome so once that observer determines that it does need to failover it loses connectivity then it
initiates the failover the primary becomes the secondary becomes the primary we put a new entry into the DNS
table so that you can your application when it gets disconnected queries the DNS again and then connects to the new
primary you'll get a new IP address reconnect to the new primary and then you'll go typically this process takes
about a minute minute to two minutes to perform the failover there is will be
some time when the new instance starts up on the new database starts up on the secondary after that then we'll
reestablish a new secondary to make sure that we put you back into a highly available configuration will start to
repopulate the secondary even if that secondary is on either the existing host
or we have to go provision a new host now one of the things that if you're caching dns entries if your applications
hold on to IP addresses then make sure that they respect the time-to-live value you want a low time to live because you
know when you go back and and and get a new IP address for the new primary you don't want it to be stale so please test
this if you're you know your applications simulate a failover you can go into the RDS console and simply
select reboot with failover you just go to your instance a reboot with failover and then it'll initiate this and you can see how
your applications behave if you're using connection pooling make sure that the connection pools behave so the next
thing that you might want to take advantage of is read replicas and so people say why would I I wouldn't need to read replicas and read replicas the
primary goal is to relieve pressure on your source database so you've got a writing node you've got a main database
and you're finding that you've got extra traffic on there and instead of scaling up the the primary you might want to
create a read replicas to sort of offload some of that most applications are actually you know read heavy not
write heavy so you can create an additional read replica another reason you might want to do it is actually
using a global read replica using a cross region read replica so let's say you've got a customer database in US
East one that's being updated continuously and you need a copy of that in u.s. West two out in Oregon because
you're gonna have a read-only copy and you've got a front-end in in u.s. West two that you want to present to your
users and you don't want to pay for the latency to go you know between across the country to go get data out in the
database so you can set up a read replica in another region it'll it'll populate that populated asynchronously
so there's no lag time there's no impact on the source database another reason
you can use read replicas is actually promoting in case of a disaster recovery so let's say in that same scenario I'm
on US East one I create a read replica in another region and then something bad happens I lose a database I lose a
application the whole region disappears which hopefully we never ever will happen but so in that case you can you
can populate you can actually promote the secondary the the source database sorry you can promote the replica to be
the new source database to be a new master database and then use that for your applications and recover quickly
the last scenario is kind of nice is you can upgrade the Reeb replica to a new
version of the database so let's say you're testing out you want to test out the latest version of of my skew or the latest version of
Postgres but you don't want to impact your working database so what you can do is you can create a read replica you can
upgrade that to the new version you can actually disconnect it if you want and run your tests on this new version so
you get a full copy that you can run against and then when you're ready you can actually either promote that one or
you can upgrade it the source database so lots of scenarios lots of useful
things around read replicas supported for MySQL Murray TV and PostgreSQL
Amazon Roar also has a notion of read replicas it's a little bit different in that it works on a stayer shared storage
architecture so instead of getting a second copy of the database you just have additional reader nodes on the the
storage architecture so this is for all the the EBS based for the EBS based engines so I've talked about multi a-z I
talked about read replicas and you know they both get copies of the data so why would you use one versus the other so put together this just to sort of
help you decide you know which is right for your scenario multi a-z is synchronous so every block is written to
both copies both sides of the of the database read replicas are asynchronous so there is potentially a replication
lag depending on the distance between your source and your target so you need to accommodate for that you know that
that lag between the source and the target in a multi AZ configuration only the
primary instance is available so even though you have a secondary there that's waiting in case of a failover only the
primary instance is actually active and then we switch over and start the database once it's on the secondary in a
read replica all of the replicas are active so you can use them for read scaling there are full databases running
and and you can use them for read scaling for multi a-z we actually
support the ability to take your backups I'll talk about backups in a minute from the secondary so reducing any sort of
impact on the primary read replicas you don't really need a backup because they're read-only copies you can
recreate them at any time multi agency is oles to availability zones in a single region so exactly to
read replicas could be either within the same AZ as the source database it could be cross
savesies or a cross region so you can you get that option when you create your read replicas versions so when I upgrade
a multi AZ configuration the version of the database upgrades at the same time so both sides because it's a synchronous
copy or upgraded simultaneously that does mean that when you have a multi AZ configuration that we do have some some
downtime when we upgrade the database and we go to a new version of the database we will experience a downtime
because we have to restart the database reapply any of the changes that have occurred read replicas they're
independent database engines so you can actually upgrade read replicas independently from the source database
and as I mentioned that's a really good strategy if you're testing out a new database version with your application
and finally with multi a-z you get that automatic failover when we detect a
problem we automatically failover although you can promote a read replica to be a standalone database that's not
automatic that you have to manually go in you can write a script you can go through the console and you can promote
that this part of your disaster recovery if you want to promote that so in reality we see lots of customers who use
both who use multi AC for their production database and then create a set of read replicas from that multi a-z
configuration so backups are another thing that if you're running your own
database you have to spend a lot of time managing your backups and managing the backup metadata and making sure that
your backups are good and with Amazon RDS its built-in we have two types of backups in RDS we have our automated
backups these are a window of backups in which you can do point-in-time restores and then we have manual snapshots where
you can go in either using the CLI or the API you can take a full snapshot of the database and store that for later
now RDS uses EBS I'll let Emma's on EBS snapshots and those snapshots are stored
off in s3 now they're not stored in your s3 buckets they're stored in the the RDS
accounts buckets and you manage them through RDS API so you don't don't go to s3 and expect the the snapshots to be
there we're managing on your behalf and you access them through the RDS API now in addition to support point in time
restores the point-in-time restores the ability to effectively rewind the database to anytime that you want within
a period so let's say something bad happened yesterday at 4:00 you can say I want to rewind the database to yesterday
at 3:55 and you can do that point time restore in order to support that we store the transaction logs so we take a
full backup in the database every night and then we store the transaction logs every five minutes and we ship those off
to s3 and then when you restore the database we're actually going to replay those transaction logs and get your
database back to the point where you want it to now the nice thing about backups because they're done by EBS is
there's no performance penalty for them at all there's not any sort of load on
the database server that you'll have so you can take as many snapshots as you
want you don't have to worry about them impacting your server as I mentioned before you can see here in the in the
diagram we've got our availability zone one this is a multi AZ configuration and we're actually taking the snapshots off
of the volumes attached to the host in availability zone too often the secondary host transaction logs were
then being pushed each five minutes into s3 then you can then also take a cob
shot and you can copied across regions so let's say you want to have you want to store that snapshot in another region
for disaster recovery you can restore it later or you just want to save the database at a certain point in time
we'll keep that around for you so wouldn't you use these different techniques so an automated backup you
specify your retention window it's super easy it defaults to seven days you can get up to 35 days and we'll let you do
point-in-time restores to anytime in that window manual snapshot so you go through the the AWS console you select I
want to take a snapshot now you give it a name and we'll keep that keep that forever so automated backups will
eventually leave the backup windows so if you have a seven-day window anything after eight days will be deleted and and
move out manual snapshots when you take them they're there forever until you delete them so you can keep them around
you can keep them for four years and restore them if you need to automated backup support that notion of
point and time recovery so a specific time during the day and then manual snapshots restores to that exact

then run your tests against basically a copy of your production environment any you know environmental changes you're
making or maybe a final copy before you delete it so I will save one off in case you you were didn't want to delete that
so restoring a database so how do you restore the backup as I mentioned that
is the two ways you either do the point-in-time restores you can see in the top right you specify the restore time or you so go to the snapshot you
say I want to pull this snapshot back now restoring creates an entirely new database since it doesn't affect the

set of storage it doesn't change the one that's running so even if it's a point in time restore that one's still there
so you'll get that new instance configuration you can specify the instance I of the storage you will get

people say why does it take so long it can take for large databases it can take a significant amount of time for them to

storing the backups in s3 and what happens is is that we make the volume initially available to the database so
we we get the volume ready but then the blocks are pulled in as they're needed so berths are pulled in from s3 and so
when you're initially restoring a database and starting it up it can be slow until some of those blocks come in
now we're working with the amazon EBS team in order to pre hydrate to warm
that quicker so that those blocks come in faster but just be aware that you know when you we restore a large
database and you want to get that up to speed it will take take a while until your basically pulled in all the blocks ways
to mitigate that is to make sure that you've got an instance class with high i/o capacity so if you're restoring
something you can use a larger instance than you might in production at least for that initial restore and you could
scale it back down and then you want to maximize the i/o so maybe you want to use provision die-offs or other ways to
really maximize that Oh IO for the restore so we also get a lot of

granting access to their database so we use identity access management to determine who can do what - your RDS

you know set up templates so that you make sure that only people can create databases delete databases you want to

here we have your master keys that are created or managed by you and then each individual instance will have its own
data key and the master key is used to encrypt the data key and the data key is used to encrypt the data and this allows

15-minute maintenance window and if we have any maintenance operations that
causes downtime now that doesn't happen very often we try to as much as possible don't cause any downtime but it will
happen a couple of times a year but if it happens it will happen in that maintenance window so so don't think
that just because it's Wednesday night it at midnight that you're gonna get a maintenance event you're gonna have disruption but if we do have a
maintenance event it will go in that window most of the operating system level maintenance that we do most of the
patching of the OS or patching of the RDS control software on the box is done without any database restart your
database will keep running serving connections and will patch behind the scenes now if you're upgrading the
database to a new version you're going from a new version of post Crestor new version of MySQL that does
require some downtime because we have to apply the new engine binaries through the and then apply any upgrade scripts
to that now minor versions are either automatically scheduled so when you create your instance you can say I want
to opt into minor version upgrades so let's say you want to go from my sequel
5 7 10 to 5 719 automatically so when we
set a new minor version as preferred then we'll upgrade within a the next
maintenance window major version upgrades are always manually applied so those are up to you because they
typically have changes to the engine that may cause application compatibility issues so you'll want to see those we do
what time to time also deprecated versions so for example if a version goes out of support or it contains bugs
that you know are causing problems in the fleet that we've seen we do deprecated versions will always give you
a notice when we deprecated a version when a version is going away for minor versions we'll give you a three-month notice and then for major versions we'll
give you a six-month notice those notices appear on you'll get an email but we all get a lot of emails so
they'll appear on your personal health dashboard as well so there's a little icon up at the top of your console that
has a list of maintenance events and so you'll see this database version is being deprecated and it'll be an upgrade
will be applied automatically within your maintenance window but you will get time to plan for that I do encourage you
that if you get a maintenance notification from us you know go ahead and plan that and do it don't wait till

bills are a little bit complicated but they break down into three key piece your database instance hours all right
so this is going to be depending on what region you're in what your instance type is what the engine you picked and then
if you're using a license included Oracle or sequel server that'll be included in that instance
so that's you're building that in instance hours your storage your provision storage for Amazon EBS or your
consume storage for Amazon Aurora you'll get a storage bill that's billed in gigabyte months now along with the
storage you may have it some additional charges for if you're using provisioned I ops you'll be charged for the amount
of I ops that you're actually provisioned and that's not a variable amount so if you say you want 10,000 I ops you're going to be billed for that
each each period whether you're actually consuming i--once or not now for i/o for
Aurora and for magnetic volumes we also charge you in millions of i/o requests there's additional charge and the final
component is your backup storage so it's the aggregate size of the backup that you've got that we're storing off an s3
now there's no charge for backup storage to the size of the volume and what that
means is that if you've got a 1 terabyte database that means we'll store one terabyte of backups at no charge and
only when you go beyond one terabyte that will start to charge you per gigabyte 1 a lot of folks who have
larger databases but are using perhaps a small portion of them you know they're using a you know 2 out of 5 terabytes
will ever actually see backup charges at all because they don't consume enough backup the final piece is the the data
transfer piece and that's similar to other services there's no cost for transferring data into your Amazon RDS
instance copying data in is is free copying data out so if you're doing lots
of bulk exports or if you're moving lots of data from region to region so the on the out you could see the data transfer
charges data within the V PC within the the the AC obviously that's that's not
that doesn't count as data transfer so a lot of folks never even see transfer charges so on your bill itself it's
going to be you're gonna see relational database service all the RDS charges are grouped by regions for using multiple
regions will see those grouped and then within that instances are grouped by engine and you'll see both reserved
instances and on-demand group together a real great tool if you haven't used it
is the AWS cost Explorer it just got an upgrade I think last week you can
get a graphical breakdown you can break down my instance type you can bake down region and break down analyze your bill
that's really nice tool for doing that and then if you really want all the the
gory details for billing they have the cost and usage report that's a detailed
line by line each hour shows you exactly what you're consuming an AWS and how how
you're being billed for it you do have to turn that on it's not on by default if you haven't used that and it stores
that on in an s3 bucket you give it an s3 bucket and each hour it pushes out a very detailed cost report for you if you
want to bring that into a lot of companies like to pull that in and bring it into their own database so they can

want to tag say your production resources or a department you can set those tags on those resources and then
